description.narrative: IFC, acting for its own account and in its capacity as implementing entity of the Private Sector Window of the Global Agriculture and Food Security Program (GAFSP), is considering to invest a minimum of US$ 3 million alongside other investors including TLCom who will invest up to US$ 4 million in the Company. Launched in 2014, Twiga is a fast growing, mobile-based B2B m-commerce platform using technology to enhance supply chains by more effectively and rapidly consolidating highly fragmented supply and demand. Starting with the large target addressable mass-market Fresh Food and Vegetable (FFV) segment, Twiga more efficiently matches supply and demand between small-scale vendors and small-scale farmers. By cutting out multiple layers of middlemen, Twiga eliminates wastage and inefficiencies in the FFV value chain, ultimately resulting in lower food prices for mass market end-consumers. Twiga offers stable, transparent prices and guaranteed offtake for farmers and convenience and reliability for small-scale vendors, e.g. street sellers and kiosks through the platform. Twiga started off with bananas, but has since grown to include other produce such as mangoes, potatoes, onions, tomatoes and cabbages and plans to onboard more products in the near future.

This Project will result in positive outcomes for key stakeholders in the agricultural supply chain (farmers and vendors) and the environment at large. - Smallholder farmers: The Project will (i) increase access to markets through guaranteed off-take (ii) increase prices (iii) increase efficiency through transparent pricing, swift digital payments and technical assistance, which will result in increased productivity - Small Scale Vendors: The Project will (i) increase access to supply (ii) improve quality of produce (iii) improve productivity, which will result in increased vendor incomes - Reduce Post-Harvest Food Loss: The Project's post-harvest food loss rate is expected to be 5%, significantly lower than the 30% in the traditional market.
The Project will also result in improved market outcomes by increasing competition in the sector through innovative channels which compel industry players to improve on quality and pricing of produce in order to compete. The Project will enhance integration of different stakeholders in the agricultural value chain working towards increasing farmer productivity. In addition, the Project could increase access to new services (e.g. credit) by reducing informality and demonstrating that farmers can be reached in a commercially sustainable way through technology
